was recorded until now.
Malone: Basically, I just released the song on SoundCloud not sure if people would like it. All of a sudden
I'm getting tweets from artists like Wiz Khalifa and Mac Miller saying they like my song. I can remember the
song having like 7,000 plays and I was so happy about that and now the video is currently close to over 250
million views on YouTube.

content.text:
Okay, I am aware that Nirvana probably recorded this tuned down a semi tone and in drop D tuning, these
chords are for people, (like me), that hate tuning and retuning guitars.
The chords seem VERY simple to me and if I've missed some out feel free to tell me but I have written out
what I can hear. The rhythm guitar on this song is minimal but I think these chords fit pretty well
Lyrics may be a little off, (nest of salt? next assault?)

content.text:
* It has been recorded three times: in November 1979 as a Peel Session, in January 1980 at Pennine Sound 
Studios, in March 1980 at Strawberry Studios (slightly slower ?). 
See https://www.discogs.com/fr/Joy-Division-Love-Will-Tear-Us-Apart/master/5095 for more informations. 
I used the Strawberry version, used in Substance and the official video: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zuuObGsB0No
* Note that longer mixes (12) also exist with longer interludes and additional interlude and chorus 
at the end.
* The A7sus2/E is played by Bernard Sumner in https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Z6DlCl6jvQ. In the original, 
the bass is playing fundamentally an A. A Dsus2/A 5707xx can also be interesting, mixing D and A notes. 
An A5 also sounds good if you sometimes stroke the G string (577(0)xx).
* The riff comes from the same video (note that Sumner uses a capo 2 because of his voice, but the 
original is in Em).
* Novices can simplify the sequence "Em  D  Dsus4  D  Dsus2  Bm   D A" by playing "Em D Bm A". 
If you have problems with the Bm chord, try playing it xx0432. The D A can also be replaced by Dsus2 A 
or even G6/D A, where G6/D is xx0000.
* Some ideas for variations: you can alternate A and Asus2 (x02200) and also use some Asus4 (x02230). 
And inserting Bsus2 (x24422) in Bm can also add some interesting color. I like for example 
[ch]Bm[/ch] [ch]Bsus2[/ch] [ch]Bm[/ch] [ch]G6/D[/ch] [ch]A[/ch] [ch]Asus2[/ch] A.
* You can sing a slower version in Adrian Borland's way ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zj_f_vKlZm0) 
which is the more profound and moving cover I know, in my opinion as good as the original although 
sounding different.

Song: April come she will
Artist: Simon and Garfunkel
Composer: Paul Simon
Album: Sounds of silence

Tabbed by DJ ('DiddyD' at ultimateGuitar.com)
28th Oct 2016

FINE TUNING:
The original album track is quite sharp of concert pitch,
the backing track was probably sped up slightly before
the vocals were added. To play along with the album track
you will need to tune all the strings up approx.(+30) 
using a chromatic tuner. 

Or play along with a live version, see links below...

Here's a link to 1981 New York concert video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IA052y131gc
This live version is in concert pitch, but a tone higher
than the record (Capo at 3rd fret - it will then sound in Bb)

Play the G chord with the ring, middle and little fingers
and for the changes to C/G use the index and middle finger
to hammer-on the notes on the 2nd and 4th strings leaving
the ring and little fingers where they are.
The Dadd4 chord is just the C shape moved up two frets.

Time signature:
The song is in 4/4, except for a bar of D in 2/4 in 
the intro and the coda

CAPO: 1st fret for original studio version 
(Will then sound in the recorded approx. key of Ab)

N.B.
Please IGNORE ANY POP-UP CHORD BOXES the website
